episodes.summary: To make the most of our lives as writers, we must understand the core principles and defining moments of being an author.

episodes.title: The Writer's Guide to Punctuation
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: When we choose the wrong punctuation in the wrong place, the result is the readerly equivalent of coughing over too much cayenne pepper.

episodes.title: The Case of the Vanishing Setting
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Authors see everything so perfectly that we don't always realize we're not providing the reader the necessary details to allow him to see the setting.

episodes.title: Why I Hate Grammar Nazis - And Why Am One
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: To be effective in sharing our knowledge with the leetspeakers, we have to realize why most people hate the guts out of Grammar Nazis and then approach with caution.

episodes.title: Don't Let Multiple-Character Scenes Run Away With You
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: How do we juggle scenes in which multiple characters are all supposed to be acting and talking?

episodes.title: How I Learned to Write - And How You Can Too
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Even the Margaret Atwoods and Stephen Kings had to log their time as frustrated, fearful authors who had no idea what they were doing.

episodes.title: Don't Drown Your Readers in Explanations
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Always be aware of why you're including a particular explanation, then reevaluate it to determine its value and don't be afraid to chop it if it's interrupting the information that's of true importance to your story.

episodes.title: 12 Writing Resolutions for the 12 Months of 2012
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: This year, instead of making a complete list of writing resolutions for the whole year, try implementing one new resolution every month.

episodes.title: The Christmas Gifts I'm Most Thankful For This Year
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Today, I'd like to share a little bit of my own holiday cheer with a list of the (mostly) writing-specific gifts I' thankful for this Christmas.

episodes.title: How Do You Decide Which Story You Should Write?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Although sorting through our fat idea folders can sometimes seem like an overwhelming challenge, don't forget that an abundance of ideas is an author's greatest blessing.

episodes.title: 25 "Under $25" Christmas Gifts for Writers
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: You might find the perfect gift for the fellow writer on your list - or you may find something to add to your own "Dear Santa" list!

episodes.title: Are Your Flashbacks Flashy or Flabby?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: To flashback or not to flashback? Sooner or later, that's a question every writer is confronted with.

episodes.title: Action/Reaction - The Pistons Powering Your Story
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: It's vital  the author understand the differences between action and reaction, so he can identify which course is preferable at key moments in the story

episodes.title: 4 Reasons to Mimic the Masters - and 4 Reasons Not to
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Copying another writer boils down to nothing more or less than mimicry, and mimicry, as we all know, is one awesome compliment.

episodes.title: How Do You Know Which Rules to Break?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: When the writing gurus tell you to be brave and break some rules, for crying out loud, which rules are they talking about?

episodes.title: Do Readers See Your Characters the Way You Want Them To?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: When you write your story, but particularly as you revise, be on the watch for the balance that emerges about your character from the details you present.

episodes.title: 10 Fear Busters for Writers
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Let's take a look at ten methods for cracking our whips at our fears and forcing them to respond to our shouts of "back, back, vicious beast!"

episodes.title: 5 Elements of a Resonant Closing Line
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Explore the five elements that will help you craft the kind of closing line that caps your entire story and leaves readers with a feeling of unforgettable resonance.

episodes.title: 5 Fun and Easy Ways to Lengthen Your Word Count
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: In comparison to giving your overweight manuscript liposuction, fattening up an anorexic story often feels like trying to create something out of nothing.

episodes.title: The Dangers of Character Overload
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: When authors are dealing with large casts of characters, readers sometimes find themselves in grave danger of character overload.

episodes.title: What Elements Make a Good Book?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: What makes a good book? Everyone has his own take. Some readers like action, some prefer romance. Some like a little of both.

episodes.title: 5 Elements of a Riveting First Line
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: The opening line of your book is your first (and, if you don't take advantage of it, last) opportunity to grab your reader's attention and give him a reason to read your story.

episodes.title: Why Your Hero Absolutely Must Pet a Dog
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: If you find yourself with a dark character on your hands, stop worrying about whether or not audiences will like him and up the odds by giving him a dog to pet.

episodes.title: Most Common Mistakes Series: Is Nothin' Happening in Your Scene?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Let's take a look-see at some of the signs your scene may be more of the nothin' sort than the happenin' sort.

episodes.title: Why Your Protagonist and Antagonist Should Be Stuck Like Glue
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Let's take a gander at seven possible adhesives you can use to keep your protagonist and his antagonist stuck like glue.

episodes.title: Captain America's 10-Step Guide to the Likable Hero
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Likable characters require careful crafting if they're to come to life in a way that is not only believable but compelling.

episodes.title: 10 Stylistic Mistakes Sabotaging Your Story
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Make sure you're not letting any of these potentially tragic gaffes sabotage your reader's trust in your competency.

episodes.title: 7 Ways to Make Family and Pets Respect Your Writing Time
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Guidelines for getting friends, family, co-workers, and pets to respect your writing time - without your needing to resort to death threats.

episodes.title: Why You Should Kick Your Story Aside and Write a Different One
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Life is too short and too full of stories for us to spend all our time slaving away on just one book.

episodes.title: What The Story Knows Best Really Means
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: The phrase "the story knows best" is a pie-in-the-sky concept used by writers to describe the indescribable.

episodes.title: Deus Ex Machina: Latin for Don't Do This in Your Story
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: This plot device might have worked for the ancient Greeks and Romans, but for modern authors it presents a number of difficulties.

episodes.title: The Fast and Easy Guide to Writing Characters of the Opposite Gender
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Writers too often create unrealistic characters by imposing their own perceptions (or fantasies) onto the opposite sex.

episodes.title: Is Your Opening Line Lying to Your Readers?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Your opening line may be bristling with energy, danger, and barbed fishhooks with which to reel in your readers, but if the paragraph that follows pulls the old switcheroo, your reader is more likely to be irritated than impressed.

episodes.title: Why There's No Such Thing as a Writing Expert - And Why That's a Good Thing
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: No matter where we are in our writing lives, no matter how many bad stories we write, no matter how many good stories we write, no matter how much we've learned or how much we've mastered - we still don't know anything.

episodes.title: Save Your Readers From Boredom: Five Fool-Proof Preventatives
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: If you can avoid these five boredom bombs, you can slay reader apathy before it starts and keep them riveted from page one all the way through to the end.

episodes.title: 4 Tricks for Picking the Perfect Word
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Let's explore four sophisticated linguistic techniques for choosing and using words.

episodes.title: Is Your First-Person Narrator Overpowering Your Story?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: The first-person narrator, more than any other type of narrator, is inclined to lapse into self-centered telling, in which he overpowers the story, at the expense of the other characters and even the plot itself.

episodes.title: Are Happy Endings a Must?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Few of us would want to subsist on a steady diet of tragedy, but all of us are better for having occasionally cleansed our reading palate with the astringent bite of these unflinching portrayals of bittersweet truth.

episodes.title: The Kung Fu Panda Guide to Writing Action Scenes
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Fight scenes, chase scenes, and other action extravaganzas appear in stories of every genre, so consider these tips to make sure yours are legendary

episodes.title: The Secret Ingredient of Original Stories
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Are there any original stories left to be written? And, if so, how do you find one to write?

episodes.title: Ideas for Constructing Your Own Writing Routine
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Organizing my daily writing routine into a series of specific steps helps me get the most out of every minute I spend writing.

episodes.title: Understanding - and Accepting - the Reasons You Write
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: At the end of the day, what's important isn't so much understanding the reason you write as it is accepting that you don't always need an explicit reason.

episodes.title: What Is a 50-Page Edit... and Why Will It Rock Your Story?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: The 50-page mark is the perfect place to stop and remember where you've been, so you have a better idea of where you're going.

episodes.title: How Not to Use Speaker Tags and Action Beats
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Let's a take a look at two means for indicating speakers and varying the rhythm of speech and narrative: the speaker tag and the action beat.

episodes.title: 3 Traits Your Hero and Villain Should Share
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: The more similar your hero and villain, the stronger your story, the more realistic your characters, and the deeper your exploration of theme.

episodes.title: 4 Ways to Avoid the Pitfalls of a Writer's Solitude
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: As important as it is to claim large chunks of uninterrupted writing time, it's also important that we make time to actually live our lives.

episodes.title: Why Writers Should Take Their Own Advice
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: If you've ever found yourself wishing for a writing mentor - someone with the savvy, experience, and generosity to reach down and guide you in your own writing journey - today's your lucky day!

episodes.title: Why Vague Writing Is Weak Writing
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: As the creator of our worlds and our characters, we don't have to wallow in the quagmire of vague details and fuzzy ideas. We can make statements of authority because, if we're not the authority in our stories, who is?

episodes.title: Are You Asking These Important Questions About Your Fantasy Setting?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Even if you already have a good idea of the specifics of your world, taking the time solidify your ideas by answering these, and other, questions can inject more life and realism into your setting and allow you to spot flaws and inconsistencies.

episodes.title: What I Love Lucy Can Teach You About Writing Tics
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Some words are overused so often that they find their way onto the Wanted: Dead or Alive list of practically every author, agent, and editor (not to mention reader).

episodes.title: 8 Signs Your Writing Is Stuck in a Rut - And Why You Should Care
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Thanks to laziness and fear - and often oblivion - it's much too easy to fall into comfortable patterns that eventually descend into blatant repetition.

episodes.title: Are You Confusing Readers With Poor Cause and Effect?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: If you can strengthen the narrative of your story by showing a logical progression of cause and effect, you'll end up with leaner prose, more honest character reactions, and more involved readers.

episodes.title: The Good News? Writing Never Gets Any Easier
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Recognizing, and even appreciating, the fact that writing will always be difficult, frees us from the doubt, and even guilt, of feeling we'll never be good enough - because the truth is we won't.

episodes.title: Why You Should Read the Type of Stories You Write
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Studying stories of the type you want to write is legitimately important research, and don't let anyone tell you differently.

episodes.title: 10 Steps for Getting Past the "This Stinks" Blues
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: No story is perfect; no author is perfect. This is a sad fact that every writer has to face sooner or later.

episodes.title: Are You Using "There" as a Crutch?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Whenever you see the word "there" used as a pronoun, you can be sure it's being used as a crutch to hold up a weak and passive sentence.

episodes.title: 10 Writing Resolutions You Can Fulfill
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: When we focus on the goals that are slightly more achievable, we're not only more likely to pull them off, but we'll also feel much better about ourselves come next year.

episodes.title: 7 Reasons Weather Is a Writer's Friend
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Weather, like most description, is best delivered in small doses, interspersed with the action and dialogue, and offered only when important.

episodes.title: Are Your Verbs Showing or Telling?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Keep your eyes open for places where you can effortlessly strengthen your scene by using verbs that show instead of tell.

episodes.title: 8 Reasons to Let Your Story Ripen
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: It takes time and breathing space for us to figure out which ideas are worth committing to for the long haul.

episodes.title: What Kind of Writer Are You?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: It's vital that each author discover for himself the methods that work best for him.

episodes.title: Description: Friend or Foe?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Avoiding description is impossible, and attempting to avoid it does nothing but tie an author's hand.

episodes.title: Why Are You Writing This Story?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Figure out what makes this story more worth writing than any other story, and let that reason empower you in every subsequent word you write.
tags: Snoopys Guide to the Writing Life

episodes.title: Are You Dating Your Fiction?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Pleasing both our present and future readers can seem like an impossible task. But with a little bit of foresight and practicality, we can sidestep the most egregious pitfalls.

episodes.title: Juxtaposition: The Power of the Unexpected in Fiction
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: One of the easiest ways to add depth to a story is to introduce one of the most marvelous techniques known to writers: juxtaposition.

episodes.title: Use Motion to Spice up Your Scenes
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: A character who's moving - even if he's just walking across the street - gives the reader the sense that the story is moving forward along with him.

episodes.title: Love Your Characters - Or Else!
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: When we write from a character's POV, we must become that character - and that means that if we fail to love him, we will fail to understand him and, as a result, end up looking down our noses and sermonizing.

episodes.title: Is Your Dialogue Pulling Its Weight?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: It's easy enough to make our characters talk to each other and even relatively easy enough to make what they say interesting to the reader. But if interesting is the only burden our dialogue is carrying, it's not doing its share.

episodes.title: The Worst Writing Advice
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Some of the worst advice ranges from downright discouragement to bits that perhaps are specific only to some of us.

episodes.title: The Best Writing Advice
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Because writing is an art form that can largely be learned, and because it is a craft that can always be perfected, most writers learn early on to study to show themselves approved.

episodes.title: Are You a Writer?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: It's much too easy for us - no matter where we are on the writing ladder - to feel that what we're writing isn't important enough to qualify us for a full-fledged Writer Card.

episodes.title: Research: When in Doubt, Make It Up
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: So long as you've exhausted your avenues of research, and so long as you've got a little chutzpah on your side, you can fake what you don't know, and readers will never notice the glue between the cracks.

episodes.title: Is Your Story Mysterious Enough?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: The specifics of the mysteries in every story will differ according to each story's demands, but following are some general guidelines on what information an author can and can't safely withhold.

episodes.title: Should You Edit As You Go?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: In order to decide whether you should edit as you go or not, you need to evaluate your writing methods and decide whether or not perfectionism is likely to slow you down to the point where that first draft will never get written

episodes.title: Are You Benefiting From the Intimacy of Pronouns?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Using pronouns to replace character names, whenever possible, creates a seamless flow of narrative that puts the focus on the what and how of your scene once you've established the who.

episodes.title: 5 Steps to Dazzling Minor Characters
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: For every vivid minor character with whom you surround your protagonist, you'll be able to give readers one more reason not to put your story down.

episodes.title: Whap! Pow! Zing! - How Can You Tell if Your Story Has Emotional Resonance?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Even perfectly crafted books can't always guarantee an emotional reaction from readers. So how do you go about infusing this all-important essence into your fiction?

episodes.title: Why Your Character's Motive Matters
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Readers want to understand a character by seeing what he does. However, often, it's what a character wants to do that matters even more.

episodes.title: 6 Reasons a Premise Sentence Strengthens Your Story
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: All stories begin with a premise. But, often, our original conceptions are hazy and unformed.

episodes.title: Is the Thesaurus Your Friend?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: If you feel that a thesaurus would benefit your writing, why not  use it? In my case, the benefits far outweigh any drawbacks, and my thesaurus remains a valuable tool in my writing toolbox.

episodes.title: Should Stories Be Soapboxes?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: When you strip fiction down to its essentials, the authors viewpoint is all there is. He may mask it artfully in the colorful garb of diverse characters and impartial dialogue, but if he's not willing to share with his readers his own passionate worldview, he's not giving them anything more than fluff.

episodes.title: Why No Writer Knows What He's Doing
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: If we flip the coin on its head, and look at the other side, we discover some mighty interesting benefits to this seeming defeatism, including the marvelous commiserative comfort of knowing that even the likes of Hemingway and Goldman struggled with getting a story to work.

episodes.title: Change is the Key to Powerful Character Arcs
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: You can come up with the most entertaining, marvelous character imaginable, but unless you also give him a strong and convincing character arc, his story will lack depth and power.

episodes.title: Maximize Your Story's Inciting Event
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: The inciting event is the moment your character's world is forever changed. It knocks over the first domino in the line of dominoes that forms your plot.

episodes.title: 8 Ways Writing Longhand Frees Your Muse
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Returning to the caveman technology of pen and paper can have a surprisingly freeing effect on our muses.

episodes.title: Generality Is the Death of the Novel
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: The difference between specific fiction and general fiction is the difference between stories that come to life and stories that lie dead on the page.

episodes.title: Creating a Functional Writing Station
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: It's important to discover the atmosphere that best encourages your creativity and foster that atmosphere as much as possible.

episodes.title: Improve Yourself, Improve Your Writing
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: We're all striving to be the best writers we can be. But the only way to be a better writer is to be a better person.

episodes.title: When Your Story Doesn't Turn Out Like You Planned
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Chances are good that our stories will never quite live up to our expectations, but the challenge of bridging the chasm between idealized concept and finished product is one of the joys of the craft.

episodes.title: 10 Ways to Write Skinny Sentences
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: If we want our characters and plots to hit the reader to the fullest effect, we have to put our sentences on a strict exercise regime that will let them emerge buff and trim and strong enough to the bear the weight of our stories.

episodes.title: Why Character Stereotypes Are a Good Thing
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Because stereotypes are widely recognized, they provide us common ground with the reader. From that starting place, we then have the option of using the reader's expectations to our advantage in any number of ways.

episodes.title: Daydream or Die!
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Too often, in the mad rush of life's busy work, daydreams are relegated to the shadowy cellars of our minds. We'll think about them when we have time. When time never seems to come, however, our daydreams become a luxury we can't afford. But, as writers, the one thing we can't afford is not to daydream.

episodes.title: Are You Using Too Many Settings?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: We often lose sight of the fact that settings are more than scenery. They're the cohesive grounding, the foundation, of the whole story - and as such they need to be used with sparing care.

episodes.title: Does Your Story Have the Extraordinary Factor?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Readers want fiction to be extraordinary enough to thrill them with its strangeness and excitement. But they also want it be ordinary enough for them to find aspects they can relate to. So how is a writer supposed to pull off this apparent paradox?

episodes.title: What a Mouse Can Teach You About Story Arc
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Who knew furry little rodents were such experts on story arc? See the foundational art of the three-act structure acted out to perfection!

episodes.title: Rewriting Made Easy
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Rewriting is hard work, but it's also very freeing and satisfying. Raising your story to its full potential, cutting its weaknesses, and beefing up its strengths is exciting! Don't lament the work; revel in it. As E.B. White pointed out: The best writing is rewriting.

episodes.title: 15 Lessons From the Masters
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: When authors whose stories have impacted the world start talking, we start listening. Take a look at the following collection of wisdom on a myriad of writing topics. Be instructed, and be inspired!

episodes.title: Three Words That Kill Writing Procrastination
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Much as we love writing, as soon we sit down and take one look at that intimidating blinking cursor, our tendency is to start procrastinating, usually with seemingly innocent minutiae that adds up before we know it.

episodes.title: Why You Should Steal From Other Authors
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Confession time: I pilfer the wealth of other writers' words on a regular basis. I filch characters. I purloin themes. I steal plots. In other words, I am a big fat thief. And I want you to be one too.

episodes.title: Strengthen Your Story by Writing the Perfect Review
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: If you could have a professional reviewer read your book and totally get it - completely understand everything you were trying to say with your characters, plot, dialogue, and themes - what would he write about your story? Close your eyes for a moment, emotionally distance yourself from your story, and pretend you're that reviewer.

episodes.title: Plot vs. Character: Which Is More Important?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Good writing should not be about pitting plot against character, but rather about finding the harmony between them.

episodes.title: Are You Using Setting to Deepen Your Characters?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: In the best of stories, setting is an inherent key in bringing to life not just the scenery but the characters themselves. As such, it isn't something we can afford to overlook. Your answers to the following questions may show you the weak points in your setting construction and help you use it to its full potential.

episodes.title: Embrace Your Internal Editor
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: We've transformed the internal editor into a monster of epic proportions, but only because we haven't learned to utilize him. Our editor's not a fiend; he's a friend. The best friend - and the best tool - a writer can have. But only if we embrace him.

episodes.title: Are You Called to Be a Writer?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Is our talent and desire for writing a gift we're meant to use? Or is it just a harmless hobby, something to pass the time that others might pass by remodeling classic cars or playing soccer? Is our writing just a fun pastime - or is it a calling?

episodes.title: Why Word Count Goals Can Be Destructive
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: If you find you're focusing more on your word count than your words themselves, you might want to consider releasing yourself from what could end up being a habit destructive to your productivity.

episodes.title: 10 Habits of Successful Authors
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Haven't made your New Year's resolutions yet? The following list is an excellent place to start, whether you're jumpstarting your writing career, or whether you've been writing for years and need to scrape off some rust. If, by the end of the year, you can cross the following habits of successful authors off your checklist, you'll be a force to reckon with in the literary world!

episodes.title: 11 Killer Chapter Breaks
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Not every chapter needs to end with a cliffhanger, but they do need to encompass a question powerful enough to make the reader crazy to know the answer.

episodes.title: Are Your Characters Talking Heads?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: By allowing your characters to communicate with their bodies as well as their mouths, you can open up a whole new layer of nuance in your dialogue.

episodes.title: How Music Will Make You a Better Writer
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: If you haven't already done so, make music a part of your writing routine - and reap the benefits of immersion in the magical realm of stories without words.

episodes.title: Why You Should Write More Than One Genre
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Every once in a while, dare to step outside the bounds of normalcy and see what unexpected adventures you can find off the beaten path.

episodes.title: 4 Reasons I Quit Writing Exercises
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Maybe journaling is a mine of creative gems for some people. Maybe it is conducive to that sometimes elusive dance with the muse. But maybe it's also a waste of time.

episodes.title: How to Kill a Character - And Avoid Hate Mail
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Some of the most powerful stories in literature and cinema have a surprising common element: The death of a main character. At first glance, this would seem to be an instant turnoff. Why hang with a character for 300+ pages only to watch him get knocked off in the end? But the truth is, when handled properly, the death of a character can add untold power and pathos to a tale.

episodes.title: Top 7 Reasons Readers Stop Reading
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: When a reader pokes his bookmark in between the pages, stretches, yawns, and drops a novel back on his nightstand, it's a terrifying moment for both novels and novelists alike. This is the moment we've worked and sweated and prayed to avoid. And yet it's a problem that few of us will entirely escape in our careers.

episodes.title: 6 Reasons Not to Listen to Your Critique Partner
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: How do you know when to heed criticism? How do you know what's worth listening to? You can start by asking yourself the following six questions.

episodes.title: 11 Dichotomous Characters - And Why They Work
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Fiction writing doesn't offer many shortcuts or magic formulas. But today I am going to give you give you a secret ingredient in that coveted recipe for memorable and realistic characters. What is this ingredient? Dichotomy.

episodes.title: Emotional Connection: Punch Your Readers in the Gut!
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: As much as we want readers to intellectually appreciate the intelligence of our writing, we need them, even more, to react to the underlying pull of the story and its characters with utter, unthinking emotion.

episodes.title: Should You Outline Backwards?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Facing the wide, blank unknown of a story can be scary. Putting one foot in front of the other, when you're unsure of the terrain, can be overwhelming. But when you can work your way backwards from a known plot point, finding your way becomes as simple as filling in the blanks. And the result is a story that falls into order like a row of expertly placed dominoes.

episodes.title: Why You Should Be Writing Scared
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Whenever your comfort zone starts getting too comfortable, it's a sure bet you're no longer challenging yourself. Writing scared means pushing yourself to the limit, tackling projects that look unconquerable, and always forcing yourself to go just a little bit farther than you think you're capable of going.

episodes.title: Good Writers Are So Lazy, They Make Readers Do All the Work! by Jason Black
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Experienced writers have learned that less really is more. Readers have great imaginations, and experienced writers have learned how to tap into them to make their own work come across more vividly and more believably. Experienced writers have learned how to give only the essential details of a scene in such a way that readers imagine everything else.

episodes.title: How You Can Take Advantage of Art's Subjectivity
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Experiencing art is like watching clouds. Two people can lie on the same grassy hill, watching the same cloud formations. But how they interpret the shapes of the clouds is an entirely individual experience. You may see a poodle on a leash, while in the same cloud, I see a drag race.

episodes.title: Should You Write for a Specific Audience?
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Know your audience is a common tenet of all media. After all, if you don't know your audience, you can't give them what they want, right? Yes and no.

episodes.title: 9 Ways to Strengthen Your Beginnings
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Unfortunately for us harried writers no surefire pattern exists for the perfect opening. However, most good beginnings do share a couple traits. Following are nine.

episodes.title: Angst, Mental Illness, and Creativity by Carolyn Kaufman
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Guest post by psychologist/writer Carolyn Kaufman. Everyone talks about angst-ridden creative people, and I've had several readers ask me if angst is in fact a necessary ingredient for creativity.

episodes.title: It's What Your Characters Do That Defines Them
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: As writers, it's often very easy for us to talk on and on about our characters' intentions. If we're not careful, we often let our characters' mouths run away with them, as they spend chapter upon chapter sitting around discussing and planning their next move. But guess what? Most readers don't care about what your characters are planning to do. They only care when they actually do it.

episodes.title: Why Genre Writing Could Kill Your Career
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Art isn't something that thrives within set parameters. By its very nature, creativity must be free to grow beyond even its creator's initial concepts. When we sign up as genre writers - led on perhaps by our own love of certain types of literature, perhaps by the lure of the money and fame that attaches itself to successful genre writers - we may be making the best possible commercial decision a writer can make in his career. But, as artists, do we honestly want to put the money before the art? Is a career as a best-selling author worth surrendering the opportunity for deeper and broader artistic license?

episodes.title: Backstory: The Importance of What Isn't Told
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: When Ernest Hemingway spoke about the dignity of an iceberg being " due to only one-eighth of it being above water,"  he was speaking about the importance of the part of the story that isn't told. Those nine-eighths underwater are the ballast for the tiny bit that juts up to glisten in the sun. And, more often than not, those nine-eighths are almost entirely composed of one of the most important - and yet sometimes overlooked - facets of any tale. Backstory.

episodes.title: Choosing Your Character's Career With Care
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: We're defined by what we do, by our jobs and our career choices. Mention a profession (mechanic, stock broker, bull rider) and definite images and presuppositions pop to mind. As writers, we can hardly afford not to take advantage of those presuppositions when crafting our characters.

episodes.title: Sticking With a Story
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: I cannot emphasize enough the importance of sticking with a story, even when it seems beyond hope. It is true that not every story will be worth continuing, but every story is worth a second chance. Sometimes the most difficult and seemingly worthless stories are the ones that will explode into brilliance if only you grit it out and keep hacking away at them.

episodes.title: yWriter Software Tutorial
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: yWriter was designed by author and programmer Simon Haynes, who apparently saw the same needs I saw in my own writing life and was able to use his programming expertise to put together one humdinger of a program. yWriter in the quintessential organizer for writers. It allows you to see your scenes, chapters, characters, settings - and just about anything else you can think of - all at a glance. As an extensive outliner, I've found it particularly helpful in organizing my mountains of eventually undecipherable scrawl into neat, easily accessible notes.

episodes.title: Making Cliches Work for You
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: The sad fact is that, with thousands of cliches roaming about the vast landscape of the English language, it's pretty darn near impossible to write a story without cliches. This is a fact. It's also a fact that cliches are pretty much the kiss of death (pardon the, well... you know) in fiction. So how can authors go about reconciling this dichotomy?

episodes.title: 5 Ways to Pace Your Story
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Pacing is like a dam. It allows the writer to control just how fast or how slow his plot flows through the riverbed of his story. Understanding how to operate that dam is one of the most important tasks an author has to learn. Without this skill, we end up writing stories that variously lack momentum, feel uneven, become anticlimactic, and seem melodramatic.

episodes.title: Details: Bringing Fiction to Life
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: We can write the most enthralling story ever told, but if we don't artfully wield the details of that story, it will never live up to its full potential. As artists, we can't avoid looking at the big picture at the expense of even the tiniest detail.

episodes.title: Characters: Likability Is Overrated
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: At first glance, it makes sense that the likability factor would be the single most important consideration a reader has in, well, liking a character. But I'm going to posit that likability is overrated.

episodes.title: Don't Let the Big Words Die
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: It's a sad fact that modern society is no longer as literate as it once was—and most authors don't seem to be doing a lot to raise the bar.

episodes.title: Eliciting Emotion
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: Emotional responses, like all of fiction, are subjective. Due to our distinctive psychological makeups and the varied influencing factors of our individual lives, we each react differently to emotional stimuli. We can never expect to tap into the tears of every single person who reads our fiction. But if you can figure out what it is that makes one person—yourself—emotionally responsive, you can likely tap into a universal reaction.

episodes.title: Branded: Negotiating Consumerism in Fiction
episodes.author: K.M. Weiland
episodes.summary: If generality is the death of the novel, then specificity, including the specificity of brand names, must bring it life. But that doesn't negate the pitfalls of branding in fiction. Discover the two of the biggest reasons I decided it was often better to avoid specifying common and popular consumer names.
